paper_decoration.summary: The manuscript's margins are decorated with gold-sprinkled paper (zerefşân / serpme technique): fine gold particles scattered across the margin areas surrounding the text block, visible as an even, warm golden shimmer on cream/off-white paper. The text block is framed by gold ruling lines (altın cedvel) with black outer lines, forming a standard Ottoman luxury framing system. Both pages of the examined opening (p006) display this treatment. Sprinkling density appears moderate and even, consistent with standard Ottoman luxury production; image resolution does not permit subtype distinction (kalbur vs. fırça). The YEK catalogue confirms: 'Sahife kenarlari zerefşan teknigiyle süslenmistir. Cetvelleri yaldizlidir.'

technique_terms.ottoman: zerefşân (زرافشان) / serpme / yaldız serpme; cetvelleri yaldızlı

paper_decoration.details: Both pages of the opening show gold-sprinkled margins surrounding the text block. The gold particles are visible as a fine, warm golden shimmer across the margin areas. The paper ground is a warm cream/off-white. Gold ruling lines (cetvelleri yaldızlı) frame the text block with black outer lines. The catalogue note confirms: 'Sahife kenarlari zerefşan teknigiyle süslenmistir. Cetvelleri yaldizlidir.' The sprinkling appears even and moderate in density, consistent with a standard fırça or kalbur technique, though the resolution does not allow subtype distinction.

style_attribution.workshop: Consistent with standard Ottoman luxury manuscript production; Kıyafetname texts were popular in the Ottoman court tradition
style_attribution.justification: Gold-sprinkled margins with gold cedvel framing are standard features of Ottoman luxury manuscripts from the 16th-17th centuries. The Kıyafetname (physiognomy text) genre was popular in the Ottoman court. Without colophon data or more distinctive decorative features visible, precise dating is limited.

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila S. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas 17 (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Primary scholarly reference for gold-sprinkled (zerefşân / afshān) and other decorated paper techniques in Islamic manuscripts; covers production, distribution, and function across Ottoman, Safavid, and Timurid traditions.
bibliography.access_notes: Available via JSTOR (subscription required). Key reference for the zerefşân technique documented in this manuscript.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational study of paper manufacture and use in the Islamic world, including decorated paper production; provides material and technological context for zerefşân paper.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers. Leiden: Brill, 2009.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Arabic manuscript terminology and codicological conventions; provides definitions for ruling systems (jadwal / cedvel), scribal terminology, and physical description vocabulary used in this record.
bibliography.access_notes: Available in major research libraries and via Brill Online.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Türk Minyatür Sanatı.' In Türkiyemiz, no. 39 (1983): 2–12.
bibliography.relevance: Key reference on Ottoman manuscript illumination and the material culture of luxury manuscripts, including decorated paper use in Ottoman court production.
bibliography.access_notes: In Turkish. Available in specialized Turkish libraries and the Atatürk Kitaplığı.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Bibliophile Aghas (Eunuchs) at Topkapı Sarayı.' Muqarnas 21 (2004): 333–343.
bibliography.relevance: Examines the collecting and commissioning of luxury manuscripts in the Ottoman court context, including decorated paper codices in Topkapı collections closely related to the Nuruosmaniye holdings.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. The Abbasid Tradition: Qur'ans of the 8th to the 10th Centuries AD. The Nasser D. Khalili Collection of Islamic Art, vol. 1. London: Nour Foundation / Azimuth Editions, 1992.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational codicological framework for Islamic manuscript physical description. Though focused on early Qurans, the terminology conventions for ruling systems (jadwal), text blocks, and paper description are standard across the field.

bibliography.citation: Çağman, Filiz, and Zeren Tanındı. Topkapı Sarayı Müzesi İslam Minyatürleri. Istanbul: Tercüman Yayınları, 1979.
bibliography.relevance: Catalogue of Islamic miniatures in Topkapı collections; documents Ottoman luxury manuscript production including zerefşân paper use in Kıyafetname-related court manuscripts.
bibliography.access_notes: In Turkish and English. Available in major Turkish and international research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Raby, Julian, and Zeren Tanındı. Turkish Bookbinding in the 15th Century: The Foundation of an Ottoman Court Style. London: Azimuth Editions, 1993.
bibliography.relevance: Documents the material and aesthetic conventions of early Ottoman luxury manuscripts, including the integration of decorated paper within binding and page design; provides comparative context for the framing system (altın cedvel) in this manuscript.

bibliography.citation: Argunşah, Mustafa, ed. Kıyafetname. Kayseri: Erciyes Üniversitesi Yayınları, 1994.
bibliography.relevance: Scholarly edition of the Kıyafetname genre in Ottoman literature; provides text-critical and codicological context for manuscripts of this physiognomy text type, directly relevant to the manuscript's content.
bibliography.access_notes: In Turkish. Available in Turkish university libraries.

bibliography.citation: Hillenbrand, Robert. Islamic Art and Architecture. London: Thames and Hudson, 1999.
bibliography.relevance: Broad reference survey covering Ottoman manuscript arts in context; useful for situating the Nuruosmaniye manuscript within the wider tradition of Islamic luxury book production.

provenance.waqf: Nuruosmaniye Vakfı (founded by Sultan III. Osman, inaugurated 1755). All Nuruosmaniye manuscripts bear the Sultan's tuğralı vakıf mühürü (imperial seal stamp).
provenance.notes: The Nuruosmaniye Kütüphanesi was established as part of the Nuruosmaniye Mosque complex, Istanbul, endowed by Sultan Mahmud I and completed under Sultan Osman III (r. 1754–1757). Its collection of luxury manuscripts reflects 18th-century Ottoman collecting practices and includes earlier Ottoman court productions. Cataloguer for Nuruosmaniye holdings in the YEK portal: Fatih Yıldız (noted for thorough paper field descriptions).
